awd_abstract_narration:
With the growing use of crowd-sourcing, the interaction between self-forming communities and traditional organizations is increasing in importance.  Existing research has focused on factors affecting an individual's level of participation in open sourced work and on the organization of open source efforts, but scant attention has been paid to the significant strategic organizational involvement in these endeavors (75% of Linux kernel contributions are from paid developers). As design and development evolves within open communities, there are an increasing number of ways that organizations may seek to balance 'contributions to' and 'differentiation from' an open community, for reasons of cost, resource management, and time to market. 

Building on principles of public sharing, collaboration, and organizational learning, this project focuses on why and how organizations participate with open communities.  Through action research and a qualitative field study of organizations participating with the Linux open-source community, we explore how the open-source environment interacts and merges with traditional organizations. A two-by-two classification scheme is used to explore the value chain of participation for organizations that differ in their degree of contributions to a common product and degree of downstream product differentiation.   A pedagogical framework and curricular materials will be developed and disseminated to improve organizational decision making about open community involvement.

Open communities provide real options for organizations seeking to improve systems design, development, and support. This project develops a solution to a practical problem that is of value to research participants and creates new theoretical knowledge of value to the academic community involved in research and pedagogy.  It helps organizations understand and navigate the complexities of actively participating in open communities and benefit from a philosophy best characterized as 'We all give a little; we all get a lot.' A better understanding of organizational participation will enable increased participation in open communities by expanding the number and diversity of participating organizations and increase the involvement of existing organizational partners. These advances in both theory and pedagogy will improve connections among academic and practical issues regarding open communities and result in improved effectiveness in addressing major societal and organizational challenges.

por.por_cntn:
Organizations increasingly engage with open source communities to design and develop software. Consequently, as open source communities represent real options for organizational participants developing software, new structural forms are created. On one hand, open source communities afford an exchange of existing knowledge, practice, and technology among connected and interdependent constituents that benefits all. On the other hand, they afford a co-creation of new directions for knowledge and technology that benefit a select few. Whatever the form, open source communities have become part of the creative revolution of how organizations operate. At the core of this revolution are new opportunities for knowledge sharing and material exchange in the development of software artifacts: Hewlett Packard engages with open source communities in the development of print drivers; Citrix engages with open source communities in the development of hypervisors; and, NYSE Technologies engages with open source communities in the development of messaging middleware. In each case, organizational engagement centers on innovation, knowledge, methods, and technologies intended to strengthen development practices. As these engagements come of age, it is important for researchers and practitioners to continue to advance our understanding of their theoretical, managerial, and engineering complexities.

To advance our understanding of organizational engagement with open source communities, we have been active contributors within corporate, communal, and academic circles. To strengthen these engagements, we formed the Open Community Research Lab. The Lab is housed in the University of Nebraska Omaha’s College of Information Science & Technology (IS&T) and through the efforts of the Lab, we have also educated over 35 Ph.D., Masters, and undergraduate information systems and computer science students regarding the complexes of open source engagement.

With respect to corporate circles, we have presented our work to Fortune 500 organizations seeking a better understanding of corporate practices associated with open source engagement. In addition, we have contracted with organizations in software engineering work, supporting technology transfer efforts in understanding organizational engagement with open source communities. In particular, we explore how to reduce the license and vulnerability risks of open source software intake into corporate innovation streams.

With respect to community circles, we have presented our work at the Linux Foundation’s Open Compliance Summit, LinuxCon, LinuxCon Europe, and the Collaboration Summit. We have hosted an organizational-academic workshop, exploring the practical and academic complexities of open source engagements. We are active members within open source communities, dedicated to the advancement of open compliance standards, making software and standards-based contributions to relevant open source software communities. 

With respect to academic circles, we have presented our work at the University of Sydney, the University of Missouri, Case Western Reserve University, the International Conference on Information Systems, Americas Conference on Information Systems, Decision Sciences Institute, and the INFORMS annual conference. We have three published journal articles, eight conference and workshop articles, have four articles in review, and have one NSF technology-transfer grant proposal currently under review. Additionally, the project has led us to co-found the Association for Information System’s SIGOPEN with Professor Joseph Feller at the University College Cork. SIGOPEN provides important structure and support for researchers seeking a collaborative environment within which they can share, grow, and foster ‘open’ ideas.
